title: Thursday, 23rd March, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:01am

Sombre mood today, for obv reasons

PM11:01am

Road chaos outside

11:01 am
PM11:01am

PM11:01am

But for once I won't blame the stupid cycle lanes

PM11:02am

Embankment shut etc

11:02 am
PM11:02am

But let's get on

undefined
PM11:02am

Footsie flat

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Literally

PM11:02am

Whole market feels flat -- bar one or two stand out features

PM11:03am

Retail sales bounce back

11:03 am
PM11:03am

That's one notable feature

PM11:04am

Tho retail sales will not have been helped by yesterday's events

BE11:04am

Okay, well let's not overstate this.

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Yeah, sure

PM11:04am

We've lived with terror for a while now in London

BE11:05am

We've got one guy with a car, a knife and a level of derangement that leads him to commit an attrocity.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Lots of people have cars and knives, but not the latter. Is London any more dangerous today than yesterday? Nope. One could argue it's safer.

BE11:06am

That's how the market -- the lens through which we see everything here -- is reacting.

Merlin Entertainments PLC (MERL:LSE): Last: 468.00, down 5 (-1.06%), High: 473.80, Low: 466.80, Volume: 1.14m
11:06 am
easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,003, up 18 (+1.83%), High: 1,003, Low: 983.50, Volume: 498.48k
BE11:07am

If the money -- the most brutal, purest, most morally ambivalent measure we have -- isn't terribly fussed, we shouldn't spend too much time speculating about secondary effects.

BE11:07am

Let's go on to talking about underpants instead.

11:07 am
undefined
PM11:07am

As to Next

BE11:07am

Yep, to Next.

11:07 am
Next PLC (NXT:LSE): Last: 4,137, up 252 (+6.49%), High: 4,248, Low: 3,822, Volume: 1.29m
PM11:08am

You bet against Next at your peril

PM11:08am

http://www.investe...1703230700122649A/

11:08 am
PM11:08am

Tough year for them last year -- but it's such a solid performer

BE11:08am

Betting against Next has been very profitable for more than a year, to be fair. Its Christmas profit warning wasn't followed by peers.

BE11:09am

Today we get numbers that match that warning ....

11:09 am
BE11:09am

.... unchanged guidance .......

BE11:09am

.... and some comforting noises from management about fixing the range.

BE11:09am

As in, they went too fashion over the back half of 2016.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Lost the focus on basics.

BE11:10am

Too many £50 kid-sized embroidered leather jackets, not enough school-suitable winter coats.

BE11:11am

So while the outlook -- which says that the overall market remains pretty awful -- might result in a nudging down of consensus, the idea that management's back in control is worth 6% on the price.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Here's UBS.

BE11:11am

Which I think is house broker.

BE11:12am

Certainly, the analyst meeting was at UBS's odd new office at 5 Broadgate

11:12 am
PM11:12am

Very odd building taht

BE11:12am

Yep. The one that looks like a game of Nokia Snake rendered in tinfoil.

PM11:12am

It looms

11:12 am
BE11:12am

It does.

BE11:12am

Here's it looming.

BE11:12am

http://newlondonde...ct/5_broadgate_ec2

11:12 am
PM11:12am

Destroys Broadgate

BE11:13am

A darkly sinister presence over a Corney and Barrow full of braying traders. It's an odd bit of the world, that.

BE11:13am

Anyway, UBS.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

FY17 PBT £790m, down 4% year on year and in-line with Q4 guidance 12m price target 4,900p
Next Brand sales were broadly flat year on year at £4,137m but full price sales were Prior: 5,275p down -1.3%. Retail LFL was down c. -5.5% with 2.5% of new space to give sales down 3% to £2,305m. Negative cost leverage saw Retail EBIT fall 16% to £339m, with EBIT margin dropping to 14.7% from 16.9% in FY16. Directory sales were up 4.2% to 1,729m with full price sales up 3.6% aided by overseas sales up 19% to £234m.

BE11:13am

Directory EBIT increased 10% to £444m with EBIT margin increasing to 25.7% from 24.4% in FY16. After a 1% boost from lower tax rate and 2.5% boost from £188m of share buybacks, EPS was down just 0.3% and the dividend was held flat at 158p.

BE11:13am

The clothing market was weak in 2016 with a shift to other consumer categories but there is an acceptance that Next has underperformed the wider market as a result of underlying product and range issues. The focus on short game, fashionable product saw a lack of attention to the everyday staple products and although these issues have been fixed, they will not be reflected until Q2. In combination with unhelpful market trends the guidance is for Q1 sales to be at the low end of the sales range (c.-3.5%) before a recovery in Q2 and especially in H2. Average selling prices have increased by a less than expected 4% after sourcing offsets but elasticity has been as expected. A similar price increase will be required in H2 even with a greater FX headwind.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

FY18 PBT guidance maintained at £680-780m – UBSe cut to £715m from £740m
The cautious UK consumer outlook remains with real disposable income under pressure. Management believes the clothing slowdown is cyclical rather than structural. Full price sales guidance is held at -3.5 to +2.5% with an expectation of Retail EBIT margin of 12% and Directory of 25.4% which at the sales midpoint gives £730m PBT, down 8% year on year. We forecast -1.6% Brand sales growth with Retail LFL of -7% and Directory sales growth of 3% and the guided EBIT margins. The £25m PBT cut includes c£20m from the lower Retail EBIT margin and lower Next sourcing profits.
We value Next using a DCF and lower our price target along with medium term estimate changes to give 4900p. This implies a Cal 17 PE of 9.7x.

BE11:14am

And Morgan Stanley.

BE11:14am

- Next issued a post-Christmas trading statement, just four weeks before the end of its financial year, in which it guided that full year Pre Tax Profits would likely be between £785m and £799m. The outcome reported today (£790m) is therefore unlikely to surprise anyone very much (consensus was predicting £792m).

11:14 am
BE11:14am

- With the FY 2016/17 figures in line with expectations, investor interest today will centre around the outlook commentary and the profit guidance for the coming year. Back in January Next set a profit guidance range of £680m-£780m for FY 2017/18. Today it has re-iterated that guidance. However it has also stated that "we expect sales in the first quarter to be at the lower end" of this range. Given that the mid-point of this range is based on a Retail division LfL of -7%, this implies current trading is very weak indeed (which may explain why Next went on sale at the weekend). The company believes it has made some ranging mistakes this season, which it expects to correct from 2Q onwards, but nevertheless this poor start to the year will do little to reassure investors

PM11:14am

They have some fat special divis on the way

BE11:14am

- We have yet to speak to the company this morning, but given that the company has reiterated its guidance range, we think consensus earnings forecasts are unlikely to change very much today, though the risk is clearly to the downside, given the company's disappointing start to the year. Prior to today, according to Bloomberg, consensus was looking for FY 2017/18 Pre Tax Profits of £728m (give EPS of 402p).

11:14 am
BE11:14am

-Based on last night's closing price and existing consensus forecasts, Next is trading on 9.5x Cal 2017 earnings, 7.3x EBITDA with a 8.1% Dividend Yield (including special dividend payments). This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 12.1x, 7.4x and 4.0% respectively

PM11:14am

8% yield!

PM11:15am

Assuming the specials actually arrive

11:15 am
PM11:15am

Promise of quarterly 45p i think

BE11:15am

Specials rather than buybacks now Next's lost the perception that it has a grasp of its own fair value, of course.

BE11:16am

Which comes back to the management misstep stuff we were talking about earlier. It all falls into the same pot.

11:15 am
PM11:16am

hmm

PM11:16am

See Shore are citing the statement on all this

PM11:16am

n January the Board announced it intended to pay four quarterly special dividends of 45p each, it has now declared the first will be paid on 2ndMay 2017. The remaining three distributions at this stage are provisional, dependent onno significant change to market conditions or the financial performance of the business. We would also highlight the following commentary from the today’s statement regarding the preference of the Board to pursue special dividend distribution rather than a share buyback as a means of returning cash to shareholders

11:16 am
PM11:16am

We can't do quotes within quotes -- but this the following is from Next itself

PM11:17am

With the share price trading at a relatively low multiple of future earnings, some have reasonably questioned whether the Company would be better to use surplus cash to buy back shares.The lasttime the Company was in a similar situation was in 2008. At that time we were suffering from a combination of tough economic conditions, weakening currency rates and some internal product range issues. Profits were forecast to decline in the year ahead and there was much uncertainty in the wider economy as the credit crunch took hold. We took the decision at that time to halt our buyback programme

PM11:17am

n hindsight, we were wrong to not buy back shares in 2008 and we hope that hindsight will prove us wrong, onthis particular decision, once again! But at this time of significant uncertainty,we feel that the decision to buy back shares is best left to shareholders themselves. And of course, shareholders can always use their special dividends to buy shares for themselves. Perhaps we have been overly cautious but companies rarely fail for being prudent with their shareholders’ money and in uncertain times such prudence is all the more important

11:17 am
PM11:17am

n the long term share buybacks remain our preferred route for returning capital to shareholders and we intend to return to them when market and trading conditions make it appropriate.”

BE11:17am

Hm.

BE11:17am

Just reminded .... The mention of the sale this weekend in that MOST note ...

11:17 am
BE11:18am

I nipped in to the Westfield one, as it happens. Looked like they were just clearing space in the stock room.

BE11:18am

50% off some random odds and ends. (I bought a towel.)

BE11:18am

Anyway, that's Next.

11:18 am
undefined
BE11:19am

On the flipside of retail we have Ted Baker

Ted Baker PLC (TED:LSE): Last: 2,693, down 147.2 (-5.18%), High: 2,832, Low: 2,683, Volume: 42.12k
11:20 am
BE11:20am

Sales and PBT both growing double digits, reasonably solid guidance given the prevailing circumstances, 61% gross margin ....

BE11:21am

....... but, they're expensive.

BE11:21am

Jefferies incoming.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Conclusion: Ted Baker reported a solid set of finals with 16.4% sales growth (ex-FX 10.8%) to £531.0m and 12.1% rise in PBT to £65.8m broadly in-line with estimates (cons £66.1m/JEFe £67.1m). The outlook statement is suitably guarded ('external factors continue to impact trading') but a healthy order book is confirmed in wholesale with guidance for sales to grow high single digit ex-FX in 17/18 (JEFe 8.4%). Ted Baker offers 3yr 15% CAGR in EPS and a c.2% dividend yield. TED trades on 18.8x cal 18 EPS, below its 3-year average of 23x and c.40% below its peak multiple of 31x.
Detail: FY gross margins expanded 110bps (flat in H1) to 61.0% due to improved price sell- through in retail, improved mix of wholesale sales to trustee customers, and positive FX. EBIT margin was down a little to 12.6% (-40bps FY vs. flat in H1), despite a reduction in staff bonus to £nil from £2.7m in the previous year. Full year dividend of 53.6p represents a 12.1% increase YoY, broadly in-line with expectations.

BE11:22am

One thing to note in the figs is the staff bonus .....

BE11:22am

......... which is zero.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

... vs £2.7m last year.

BE11:23am

Imagine doing 16.4% sales growth and not getting a bonus. (Okay, a fair bit of that is forex but still ...)

BE11:24am

There's also a £4.5m exceptional for leases and closures, including that slightly out of place store it opened in Spitalfields.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

(@Fatdaz: I've been to that barbers. It's a bit macho.)

BE11:26am

Here's Canaccord.

BE11:26am

No numbers, as usual, in the outlook statement, but allusion to continuing impact of 'on-going external factors' in Ted's markets - namely North America and Asia. We think the company will maintain earnings growth within its target range of 12-15% - FY18E is unlikely to be a super-normal year as things stand. Our FY18E PBT of £74.2m (127.2p, 13% growth) is slightly below cons. of £75m. Shares trade on calendar 2017E PE of 22.6x. This is an excellent quality business, our 3115p TP represents 10% potential upside, but there is not enough in this statement to drive a re-rating beyond that, in our view.

11:26 am
undefined
BE11:27am

Since we're doing retail, quick line on the retail sales.

BE11:27am

Up 4.1% year on year, versus a 3.2% consensus.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Or 1.1% month on month.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:28am

Here's Kallum Pickering at Berenberg.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

The oil and employment boost is fading: The 4.4% average annual growth in retail sales ex. autos during 2015 and 2016, and the surge to 5.8% yoy in H2 2016, was totally unsustainable. Now that the boost from cheap oil is over and employment gains slow as the labour market reaches full employment, household spending will return to more normal patterns. But it looks like households aren’t ready to end the party just yet. In February, retail sales ex. autos surprised on the upside, growing 1.3% - versus estimates of 0.3% - on a monthly basis after the little over-correction in Dec and Jan. Sales ex. autos increased by 4.1% on an annual basis. All major components of retail sales expanded on the month, with discretionary spending on household goods (3.7%) and clothing and footwear (1.0%) growing at healthy rates. After rising by 1.6% qoq in Q4, well above the long-term trend of 0.7% 3M/3M, retail sales will face a little payback for the quarter overall. Comparing the Jan-Feb average to Q4 2016, retail sales ex. autos declined by 1.2%. In Q1 retail sales will likely decline on a quarterly basis for the first time since 2013. Over the medium-term, retail sales growth will likely converge towards the 20 year trend of 2.9% yoy, maybe even a little slower in H2 2016 as households adjust to rising import costs.

BE11:29am

The risks to real household spending from rising inflation are grossly overstated. We expect inflation to average 2.7% in 2017 and 2.6% in 2018 (in line with the BoE) as the c12% fall in trade-weighted sterling since the Brexit vote pushes up import costs. At this mid-stage of the cycle, growth is entrenched, unemployment low and households feel confident enough to save a little less and borrow a little more. 2.7% annual inflation is not enough to spoil the party. Suppose sterling took another 10-15% leg down and inflation hit 5%, then households would face some real problems. That, however, seems unlikely. The rise in inflation will squeeze household incomes in 2017 and 2018 even as tight labour market conditions cause a modest rise in nominal wage growth. But it is unlikely to fully pass through into real consumption growth. Instead, real household spending growth will likely ease to a little below the 20 year average rate of 2.4% yoy after above-trend growth last year. We expect real consumption growth to ease from 3.0% in 2016, to 2.3% in 2017 and 1.9% in 2018. Our outlook is broadly in line with the BoE’s survey data published yesterday – see chart. Remember, household balance sheets have strengthened since the Lehman-crisis, debt-to-income has fallen and household wealth has risen. By increasing borrowing and saving less to target a desired level of consumption, households can smooth spending over the medium-term to compensate for the modest squeezes on real incomes.

BE11:30am

Here's that chart referred to.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

BE11:31am

As to the sector ......

Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 336.82, up 11.91 (+3.67%), High: 340.60, Low: 322.70, Volume: 4.73m
11:31 am
Associated British Foods plc (ABF:LSE): Last: 2,638, up 33 (+1.27%), High: 2,650, Low: 2,595, Volume: 209.40k
Dixons Carphone PLC (DC.:LSE): Last: 311.80, up 9.3 (+3.07%), High: 313.10, Low: 301.60, Volume: 1.24m
Debenhams PLC (DEB:LSE): Last: 54.50, up 1.15 (+2.16%), High: 54.75, Low: 53.35, Volume: 1.49m
11:31 am
BE11:32am

You get the idea.

undefined
BE11:32am

Okay, Paul's had to run off to some meeting that's apparently more important than talking to you, the valued reader.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

So you have me solo for the next 30 minutes. How will we fill the time?

BE11:33am

Oh, supermarkets.

BE11:34am

I meant to wrap that into the retail stuff but forgot. Deutsche pushing Tesco.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Switch out of Sainsbury.

BE11:36am

(@Soundbuy: nothing would make me happier than to dump a page of my notebook onto here and see what happens. Sadly, though, the regulatory hinterland we move in means we need to act responsibly with scuttlebutt and grift.)

BE11:36am

Here's DB's summary.

11:36 am
BE11:37am

Given upside to revised TPs at Tesco (+27%), Sainsbury’s (+9%) and Casino (+5%), we raise Tesco (18x 2017E PE) to Buy and cut Sainsbury’s and Casino from Buy to Hold. Given the 43% downside to our target, we cut Rallye (13x 2017E PE) from Hold to Sell. Food retailers lagged the MSCI Europe by 3% in Q1. Within this were big intra-sector swings: Tesco and Metro underperformed by 13% and 11% while Casino and DIA outperformed by 7% and 6%.

BE11:37am

At c.190p, we believe Tesco is priced for c.60bps further UK & ROI EBIT margin improvement to 2.4% (vs. H1 2016 1.8%). We expect it to recover to 3.2% (140bps improvement), which gives us a DCF value per share of 240p. A worst case scenario, that the UK margin remains at 2016E 1.9%, would give us a DCF value per share of 155p. Achieving the 3.75% midpoint of the group margin ambition (3.5% to 4.0%) would give us a DCF value per share of 280p. The volatility in the share price reflects Tesco’s UK trading performance. We don’t see Tesco as being in that steady state where volume growth is the biggest driver of margin. Instead cost cutting and commercial gross margin gains are the biggest driver of margin development in the short to medium term. We expect Tesco to beat consensus expectations on UK margin at prelims on 12 April.

BE11:38am

Given strong performances over the past quarter, and reduced upside to our target prices, we downgrade Sainsbury’s and Casino to Hold. We continue to like the multi-year Argos integration story but Brexit has increased the risk to medium term general retail profits. At Casino, we continue to expect French margin recovery and financial deleverage but we see the impact of the second playing a greater role in 2018 than 2017 (cut 2017E EPS 10%). It is largely our valuation/rating on Casino that drives our Rallye target price – hence a slightly lower Casino target price and a strong rebound in Rallye’s share price drives our downgrade of Rallye to Sell (43% downside to TP).

11:38 am
BE11:39am

The European food retailers underperformed the MSCI Europe slightly, again in Q1, with share prices increasing on avg. +2%, compared to the market +5%. Both the UK and continental European names underperformed, by 3% and 2% respectively. We continued to see slightly fewer earnings upgrades/more downgrades in food retail than the overall market (MSCI Europe) in Q1 – not very surprising given the sector doesn’t benefit from sterling weakness. On 16x NTM PE the sector is trading slightly above its 5 year avg. of 15x However, on a mkt. relative PE of 1.05x it is trading slightly below its 5 year avg. of 1.08x.

BE11:39am

A wee bit more on the Tesco thesis ....

BE11:42am

.... and the Booker deal, which continues to confuse and has been related to some noise around boardroom disagreements and stuff.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

(That long pause was me trying to find a way to phrase that sentence.)

BE11:42am

Back to DB.

BE11:43am

[W]e think Tesco can deliver a small beat at its full year results on
12 April (4% on group EBIT). Within this, we think the UK margin progress will be better than expected, lending credibility to the margin recovery story. We also expect a miss from the international business but we believe investors will
value progress on UK profitability more highly.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

We are neutral on the Booker merger announced on 27 Jan but we believe a lot of investors are negative on this transaction. Our two main concerns are the timing – 1) we’re surprised management has undertaken M&A before delivering more progress in terms of the turnaround programme and 2) we think they paid a full price although that clearly reflects our positive view on Tesco’s future earnings progression and hence share price potential. On the other hand, we think the synergy targets are real/achievable and we welcome the addition of the Booker management team to the Tesco business. Beyond all of this, we think the Booker deal is less important than the core Tesco turn-around. Whether the fact that the Tesco board and management are willing to pursue this deal at this point in time, increases or decreases confidence in the stand-alone Tesco turn-around, is up for debate. We interpret it positively.

BE11:43am

Trading on 18x 2017E PE, Tesco is not obviously cheap. However, we forecast another 24% yoy growth in EPS in 2019 vs. 2018, after an expected 29% growth in 2018 and 24% in 2017. This reflects c. 15% expected growth p.a. in group EBIT and financial deleverage. Hence Tesco’s PE falls to 14x in 2018E and 12x in 2019E, when we expect Tesco to achieve a normalized UK margin of 3.2%. Tesco offers a 6.5% 2017E and 2018E FCF yield, slightly above the sector average of 6%, which we see as offering strong valuation support. While our target price is based on a DCF valuation, we also look to a SOTPs which indicates 227p value per share (please see Figure 76), using relatively conservative valuations of 0.25x EV/Sales on Tesco’s European businesses. We see the underperformance of these businesses as a potential risk but we’d expect M&A to provide valuation support in this case.

Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 188.00, up 2.15 (+1.16%), High: 189.30, Low: 186.85, Volume: 14.12m
11:43 am
J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 265.00, down 1.6 (-0.60%), High: 265.10, Low: 262.70, Volume: 2.77m
PM11:44am

(Actually I'm back. it was a health check and jsut had to take the time they offered.)

PM11:47am

PM11:47am

BE11:48am

Stobart -- the rump bit -- seemed to attract the interest of some of the warmer punters for a while. Late 2015 if I remember right. Though nothing came of it.

Stobart Group Ltd (STOB:LSE): Last: 209.26, up 2.51 (+1.21%), High: 210.50, Low: 207.00, Volume: 137.39k
11:48 am
undefined
BE11:49am

IG requested.

PM11:49am

Its onthe 250 losers board

11:49 am
PM11:49am

Down almost 4%

BE11:49am

Yep. The spread betting and regulatory football specialist. Revenue a bit weak.

BE11:50am

For reasons we know: volatility's low.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

So punters aren't getting stopped out so regularly.

PM11:50am

Q3s here: http://www.investe...1703230700112608A/

BE11:51am

The numbers show revenue per client down 15%

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Which more than offsets client growth of 13%

PM11:51am

(Cenkos doing the Stobard float, ive just been told)

BE11:51am

We also get proper KPIs! Which aren't very good.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Active clients up only +2.4%, so revenue per client down 7%.

BE11:52am

Let me cut to Barclays on how to make sense of this all.

BE11:53am

Crucially, first trades were +20%, which is very encouraging as it reinforces our core thesis that IG has become better at sourcing new customers and converting them to active clients. As a result of weaker Q3 trading, we cut FY17E revenue 3.5%, and cut EPS 4.5% to 45.2p. Whilst it is never ideal to cut EPS in stocks we rate Overweight, we are not too dismayed. Volatility ebbs and flows, and Figure 3 illustrates that the average level of the VIX index dropped 43% in Q3 FY17 vs Q3 FY16. Lower volatility leads to a decline in revenue per client, but also creates weakness in active clients (both existing as well as potential clients). Q4 is said to have “started better for IG”. We lower our PT to 600p based on lower FY19E EPS.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

..... "sourcing new customers and converting them to active clients" .... sheesh. That's a bit grandiose for a bloody bookmaker.

BE11:53am

There is little to report on regulation. The company comments that it has “responded to regulator consultations in the UK and Germany” and will update the market once there is clarity from these consultations. Despite soft Q3 trading, we believe that the key driver for the shares this year will be the policy statement from the FCA consultation which is due in “Spring 2017”.

BE11:54am

We consider IG shares to be good value, trading on a PE of 15.4x FY18E and dividend yield of 4.6%, based on a material cut to our revenue forecasts assuming lower leverage limits in the core UK market. There is an unusually wide range of potential outcomes for both EPS and the share price, but we consider the upside vs downside as attractive. If regulation in the UK is less focused on leverage limits (and more like German/French focus on ‘limited risk’ accounts), we see material EPS upside and re-rating potential (our upside case is 1043p). We believe our base case, with a 50% decline in UK revenue (ex-professionals) in FY18E is cautious, albeit there is uncertainty on how quickly costs may be cut. Our downside scenario assumes further regulation risk, driving EPS lower, and a de-rating to a PE of 10x. This creates our downside case of 255p.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

And RBC's conference call notes.

BE11:55am

(@Michael: good. Fewer people lose money. I'm in favour of them not trading.)

BE11:55am

0am management hosted a very brief call (under 10 minutes long):
l
Active leveraged clients only increased 9% year-on-year (versus 16% reported, with the difference being made up by lower quality, lower revenue stockbroking clients).
l
The CEO said that IG’s Q3 demonstrated “reasonable performance in a dull market,” and then went on to call the company’s performance “a little weak.” The company is blaming exceptionally low volatility in both US and UK markets for the weak performance.
l
There has been some discussion that higher value clients could reclassify as “professional” as opposed to “experienced retail” to avoid some of the pending regulatory restrictions which would mitigate the adverse financial impact from the prosed changes. However, IG indicated that higher value clients “like the added protections” of being classified as retail clients, and it is thus “not in their interests to be deemed professional.”

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Our conclusion from this morning remains unchanged: the regulatory overhang persists as the final regulations in the UK are announced (spring 2017); the regulations become effective (likely summer 2017); IG reworks its product offering, and revenue and profits decline (H1/FY18); financial performance stabilisation occurs (H2/FY18 at the earliest); and a financial recovery occurs (FY19 at the earliest); thus the worst is yet to come. Our Underperform rating is based upon regulation contagion to other geographies is likely; client contraction is possible, yet we do not forecast it; and financial performance stabilisation and recovery could take longer than we envision.

Redrow PLC (RDW:LSE): Last: 501.50, up 1 (+0.20%), High: 502.50, Low: 490.80, Volume: 291.64k

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Though management was doing everything it could to damp that idea yesterday.

BE11:59am

Canaccord has a decent summary of the situation.

BE12:00pm

We see the rationale behind Redrow's interest in a merger with Bovis, underpinned by: a good complementary fit of land banks with Bovis strong in the South East and Redrow having more land in the North, the Midlands and Greater London; a good management team at Redrow with a proven track record to improve returns; its potential to increase the scale of the business without stretching leverage, with potential for synergies to be extracted. The terms of any deal (cash and shares mix) and price will clearly be the sticking point.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Scope to revise up the offer. Using an element of cash would avoid further dilution for Redrow shareholders, but Bovis management highlighted this as a negative. If we assume a revised offer using all shares, an exchange ratio of c.1.6 Redrow share for each Bovis share would imply Bovis being taken out at around book value of c.790p and we estimate this would result in the Redrow 2018E NAV per share increasing from c.372p to c.440p. At an exchange ratio of 2 shares, the implied premium to Bovis's book value would be c.25% and Redrow's NAV per share would still increase by less at 400p. The ultimate outcome in terms of the price of any revised offer would depend upon the time frame, the extent of improvement and degree of risk to Redrow's management in earning a better return (by improving margins and asset turn) from the Bovis land bank. A mid-point exchange ratio of around 1.8 Redrow shares, implying a take out price of 887p (or 917p including the 30p final dividend, Ex-date 23rd March), would be a level at which Redrow would seriously consider negotiating around in our view.

BE12:01pm

Galliford Try has also proposed an all share merger. Under its proposal, Bovis shareholders would end up with 47.75% of the combined market cap. Even if Redrow were to come back with a revised proposal, the likelihood of success would also depend on the price that Galliford (GFRD-LSE : 1583p | Hold) is prepared to offer (arguably a merger with Bovis would have a more significant impact on Galliford's strategic direction) and which management team and business model Bovis shareholders would expect to obtain more value from over the medium term. Bovis could also aim to deliver an improving financial performance as an independent company.
While we would not be surprised to see Redrow return with a revised offer, we also believe it would be prepared to walk away to avoid over paying. It is able to deliver value without a merger, particularly in view of a land market that offers attractive returns.

BE12:01pm

So to recap ... might, or might not. Dunno.
